title-group.article-title: Successful Early Neovascularization in Composite Tracheal Grafts

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Otolaryngology-Head & Neck Surgery, The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center, Columbus, Ohio, USA
2Center of Regenerative Medicine, Abigail Wexner Research Institute, Nationwide Children’s Hospital, Columbus, Ohio, USA

Nyirjesy, data analysis, presentation of work, manuscript preparation; Jane Yu, data collection and analysis, review of manuscript; Sayali Dharmadhikari, data collection and analysis, review of manuscript; Lumei Liu, experimental design, data collection, review of manuscript; Maxwell Bergman, preparation of the manuscript, review of the manuscript, data analysis; Zheng Hong Tan, experimental design, data collection; Kyle K. author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Sarah C. Nyirjesy, MD, Department of Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery, The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center, 915 Olentangy River Road, Suite 4000, Columbus, OH 43210, USA. sarah.nyirjesy@osumc.edu

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial License, which permits use, distribution and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited and is not used for commercial purposes.

sec.title: Objective.
sec.p: Long-segment tracheal defects require tissue replacement for successful reconstruction. Rapid revascularization is imperative to maintain graft function. We previously showed that partially decellularized tracheal grafts (PDTG) and composite tracheal grafts (CTG; PDTG supported by a 3-dimensionally printed external splint) regenerate respiratory epithelium and may support the regeneration of endothelial cells (CD31+). However, the capability of graft endothelial cells to organize or contribute to tracheal revascularization remains unclear. In this study, we quantified endothelial cells (CD31+) and neovessel formation in PDTG and CTG. We hypothesize that PDTG and CTG support tracheal neovascularization to a similar extent as surgical (syngeneic tracheal graft [STG]) and native trachea (NT) controls.

sec.title: Study Design.
sec.p: The animal study, a randomized control trial.

sec.title: Setting.
sec.p: Center for Regenerative Medicine, Nationwide Children’s Hospital.

sec.title: Methods.
sec.p: PDTG was created via an established decellularization protocol. Segmental tracheal reconstruction was performed with STG, PDTG, or CTG using a mouse microsurgical model. NT was used as a nonsurgical control. At 1 month, mice were euthanized, grafts harvested, sectioned, and stained with CD31 and hematoxylin and eosin. Neovessel formation was quantified by the number of formed blood vessels in the lamina propria and vessel size (vessel/graft area, mm2).

sec.title: Results.
sec.p: Decellularization eliminated all endothelial cells and there were no perfused vessels at implantation. At 1 month, PDTG and CTG supported neovessel formation with tubular vessels lined with endothelial cells. There was no difference in the number or size of vessels compared to controls.

sec.title: Conclusion.
sec.p: PDTG and CTG support tracheal endothelial cell regeneration and neovessel formation. Future directions to assess the function, kinetics, and distribution of graft neovessels are needed.

body.p: Long-segment tracheal defects may arise from autoimmune disease, congenital anomalies, malignancy, or intubation trauma and ultimately require tissue replacement for reconstruction.1 A challenge behind tracheal replacement and reconstruction is the restoration of its blood supply since the trachea is vascularized mainly by small perforators along the posterolateral airway.2 Rapid neovascularization has been identified as the key predictor of successful surgical intervention in tracheal replacement, and failure of neovascularization has been identified as one of the major factors leading to graft failure.1–3 Recent solutions have focused on allograft transplantation as a means of rapidly restoring perfusion to tracheal grafts, with reported success with local tissue flaps4 and microvascular free flaps5 in preserving ciliated epithelial cell viability, maintaining chondrocyte survival, and promoting anastomotic healing.

Allogenic transplantation can often require long-term immunosuppressive medications with numerous potential adverse effects to avoid rejection.5 Due to the life-threatening implications of unmanageable tracheal disease without autologous tissue and the risks associated with immunosuppressive treatments, partially decellularized tracheal grafts (PDTG) that contains an epithelial extracellular matrix similar to the native trachea (NT) while remaining nonimmunogenic have been developed.6,7 PDTG supports rapid regeneration of a host-derived epithelium. Anticipating mechanical changes in vivo when scaling these PDTG for human use, a composite tracheal graft (CTG) composed of PDTG and a 3-dimensionally (3D) printed external splint have been developed to confer stable mechanical properties during regeneration.7

In our previous work,6 we suggested that PDTG may support the formation of new endothelial cell populations in the lamina propria, by the presence of the endothelial cell marker CD31.6–8 However, the capability of these endothelial cells to organize or contribute to tracheal revascularization remains unclear. In this study, we aimed to detect the formation of graft neovessels by quantifying microvessels based on endothelial cell population and gross morphology in the lamina propria and determine the effect of the composite airway splints on neovessel formation in a murine model of orthotopic tracheal transplantation.

We hypothesized that the number and size of neovessels in tracheal grafts with (CTG) or without (PDTG) an airway splint would be similar to NT and syngeneic controls (syngeneic tracheal graft [STG]) at 1 month.

sec.title: Animal Care and Ethics Statement
sec.p: The Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of the Abigail Wexner Research Institute at Nationwide Children’s Hospital reviewed and approved the protocol (AR15–00090). Humane care was given to all animals in adherence to the US Department of Agriculture regulations outlined in the Animal Welfare Act and standards published by the Public Health Service, National Institutes of Health in the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (2011).

sec.title: Tracheal Graft Fabrication: PDTG, CTG, and STG
sec.p: As previously described, tracheal grafts were harvested from 6- to 8-week-old C57BL/6J female mice.8,9 A 5 mm segment of the proximal trachea was excised. Syngeneic grafts were implanted in genetically identical mice following harvest without additional processing. PDTG was prepared as described previously.6 In brief, tracheal segments were rinsed with 1X phosphate-buffered saline with 1% penicillin/streptomycin (Gibco; Thermo Fisher Scientific) and treated with 0.01% (wt/vol) sodium dodecyl sulfate solution (SDS; Sigma-Aldrich) for 5 minutes. They were then washed with 0.9% sodium chloride (NaCl; Thermo Fisher Scientific) solution in 10-, 15-, and 20-minute sessions sequentially. Segments were then treated with 0.01% (wt/vol) and 0.1% (wt/vol) SDS solutions for 24 hours followed by 0.2% and 0.1% SDS for 3 hours each. Nucleic acids were cleared with 30 minutes of 1% Triton X-100 solution. Overnight, tracheas were immersed in 0.9% NaCl solution at 4°C. All procedures were performed on a shaking platform at 48 rounds/minute.

sec.title: Splint Fabrication
sec.p: 3D-printed airway splints were manufactured as previously described.7 Briefly, microcomputed tomography images of a mouse trachea were segmented to create a 3D model of the tracheal anatomy. Solidworks (Solidworks 2021; Dassault Systemes) was used to design splints that encircled 270° of the external anterior trachea without overlying the posterior wall and span a 3 mm defect and overlap the NT at each end. A 3 × 3 scaffold design supported radial traction and facilitated suturing the splint with the graft and NT. The thickness of the splint was 250 μm.

Splints were then manufactured via stereolithography 3D Printing (Form3B; FormLabs) using BioMed Amber Resin (FormLabs), and postprocessed as per standard protocols. Prior to implantation, splints were sterilized using an autoclave according to resin requirements.

sec.title: Implantation of PDTG and CTG
sec.p: Segmental tracheal resection was performed and mice were implanted with the STG (N = 4), PDTG (N = 4), or CTG (N = 4).6,7,9 A 3D-printed airway splint was implanted over PDTG to create CTG. Radiopaque markers were secured at the proximal and distal anastomoses as described previously.7 Tracheas were also harvested as a native control (NT; N = 4). At 1 month, animals were euthanized with a ketamine/xylazine cocktail, grafts, and neighboring host trachea harvested, fixed in 10% neutral-buffered formalin (NBF), sectioned, and stained with CD31 and hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Animals that did not survive to the 1-month endpoint were not included in this study.

sec.title: Histology
sec.p: NT, STG, PDTG, and CTG were fixed at room temperature in 10% NBF for 24 to 48 hours. Paraffin-embedded specimens were embedded in paraffin and sectioned into 4 μm thickness longitudinally. Sections were then deparaffinized and rehydrated prior to staining with hematoxylin (Sigma-Aldrich) and counterstaining with eosin. H&E stain of postimplantation tracheal sections was used to confirm the successful decellularization process. Bright-field microscopy (Zeiss) was used to image-stained sections.

sec.title: Blood Vessel Counts
sec.p: H&E stained NT, STG, PDTG, and CTG were used to confirm the presence of blood vessels for all animals (4 STG, 4 CTG, 4 PDTG, and 4 NT) H&E assessment was performed to qualitatively characterize intact blood vessels within the graft regions for each animal. Neovessels were identified as fully formed tubular vessels in the tracheal lamina propria with intraluminal red blood cells. Of each cohort, 3 animals from each surgical group (9 samples) had adjacent CD31 and H&E sections that were used to correlate blood vessels to endothelial cells. Blood vessels were marked and measured using ImageJ (US National Institutes of Health) for quantification. Neovessel formation was quantified as the number of blood vessels (blood vessel number/graft area (number/mm2) and the size of the blood vessels (area of the vessels/graft area (mm2) on H&E slides.

sec.title: CD31 Immunofluorescence
sec.p: Adjacent slides of H&E-stained sections were selected to detect endothelial cells. Immunofluorescent (IF) staining for the endothelial (CD31+) biomarker was completed using previously described methods.6–8,10 Briefly, we quantified 4 high powered field (HPF) images of CD31 staining in each animal and CD31 was quantified with cell number/HPF.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Statistical tests were performed using Microsoft Excel (Microsoft Corporation). Experimental data were presented as means ± standard deviations. A 1-way analysis of variance was used to test for statistical significance. Statistical significance was deemed p < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Successful graft decellularization was confirmed on H&E and immunofluorescence prior to implantation, as there was no evidence of extracartilaginous cells and CD31 staining was negative in all grafts. Out of the animals listed above, 9 had adjacent slides of both CD31 IF and H&E staining, making them appropriate for the correlation of blood vessels to endothelial cells. After 1-month postimplantation, all animals in the PDTG and CTG groups demonstrated spatially appropriate endothelial regeneration as evidenced by the presence of CD31-positive cells and findings on H&E.

All tracheal grafts demonstrated the presence of neovessels at 1 month (representative images, Figure 1). Gross examination of grafts illustrated overlying blood vessels at the time of explantation (Figure 2). Quantification of blood vessels on H&E staining demonstrated equivalent numbers of blood vessels per mm2 between PDTG (33.6 ± 15.5), CTG (16.9 ± 8.60), NT (51.0 ± 33.1), and STG (41.3 ± 5.78) (p = .5821 for PDTG vs NT; p = .1029 for CTG vs NT; p = .9390 for PDTG vs STG; p = .3125 for CTG vs STG). Additionally, the size of blood vessels over the entire graft (%vessel area/graft area) was equivalent between groups (NT: 0.998 ± 0.579; STG: 1.00 ± 0.391; PDTG: 1.18 ± 0.900; CTG: 0.785 ± 0.604; p = .9774 for PDTG vs NT; p = .9647 for CTG vs NT; p = .9782 for PDTG vs STG; p = .9637 for CTG vs STG), and CD31 quantification was equivalent between groups (STG: 49.4 ± 9.85; PDTG: 54.6 ± 11.1; CTG: 52.0 ± 12.6, p > .05 for each comparison), which suggests that both PDTG and CTG undergo neovessel formation and that these vessels are not different in number, size, or CD31 positivity than surgical and nonsurgical controls.

Before PDTG and CTG implantation, the CD31 staining was negative in all grafts and there was no evidence of any cellular DNA. Furthermore, CD31 immunofluorescence of endothelial cells formed tubular blood vessels and appeared to be distributed along the patterns of blood vessels on H&E at low power (representative images, Figure 3) and high-powered fields (representative image, Figure 4), demonstrating regeneration of endothelial cells.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Long-segment tracheal defects present a reconstructive challenge and ultimately warrant tissue replacement for defects greater than 30%.6,8 We previously developed a nonimmunogenic tracheal graft using partial decellularization that is able to produce tracheal neo-tissue in 1 month. One critical component to successful tracheal replacement is the restoration of perfusion, which we previously attempted to measure using IF quantification of the endothelial cell marker CD31, but this does not provide information on whether or not these endothelial cells organize or contribute to the process of neovascularization.

Endothelial cells have been known to lead to neovascularization which encompasses both angiogenesis and vasculogenesis to support nutrient delivery and perfusion.3,11 We found no effect of an external airway splint on endothelial regeneration. This quantification was equivalent to NT and surgical control, suggesting that both PDTG and CTG support neovascularization. Functional vascularization is critical for tracheal regeneration since it promotes the circulation of nutrients and cytokines required for effective tissue regeneration and ensures re-epithelialization on the basement membrane.12 In the current study, we also showed that PDTG and CTG undergo neovascularization, as evidenced by neovessel formation on histology 1 month after implantation. We confirmed this with both quantitative immunofluorescence and gross morphologic assessment. We also found that IF assessment of endothelial cells with CD31 consistently identified newly formed blood vessels observed on H&E, thus validating this measurement to quantify neovessel formation.

There were several limitations to this study. First, a murine model of orthotopic tracheal transplant may not be as clinically translatable due to the small size of the airway, may have less space for blood vessel infiltration, and therefore may not translate to humans. We are addressing these limitations through ongoing work with large animal models. Also, the characterization of blood vessel formation may have been skewed due to slight variations in histologic sectioning, which is compounded by the small size of the airway and small sample size. Ongoing work will include perfusion studies to confirm vessel functionality, which we will pursue in our tracheal grafts with further studies.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: PDTG not only demonstrates regeneration of a functional epithelium but also supports neovessel formation similar to NT, which is known to be a key metric of success in tracheal replacement. Further research is needed to fully characterize the perfusion of tracheal grafts as we move closer to clinical translation.

caption.p: Representative images of blood vessels (yellow arrows) on H&E slides for native trachea, syngenetic controls (syngeneic tracheal graft [STG]), partially decellularized tracheal grafts (PDTG), and composite tracheal grafts (CTG).

Gross evidence of neovessel formation of partially decellularized tracheal graft (PDTG) at 1 month after implantation. Yellow arrows demonstrate overlying blood vessels in both the native trachea and PDTG.

At implantation, there were no cells present in PDTG. After 1 month, CD31 immunofluorescence visibly corresponded to neovessel formation on H&E for PDTG and CTG and was similar to STG and native trachea. CTG, composite tracheal grafts; H&E, hematoxylin and eosin; PDTG, partially decellularized tracheal grafts; STG, syngeneic tracheal graft.

Representative high-powered image on light microscopy and immunofluorescence for partially decellularized tracheal graft at 1-month postimplantation and pattern of CD31+ distribution corresponding to blood vessel formation on hematoxylin and eosin.
